channel.title: Extragalactic
channel.description: Various objects outside of the Milky Way galaxy.

item.title: M82
item.description: M82 taken with Celestron 11-inch and the Canon T5i. M82 is the small companion to M81 and their interaction is suggested by radio imagery. It is of type I0 (irregular) and is the closest starburst galaxy to our Milky Way.
item.media:description: M82 taken with Celestron 11-inch and the Canon T5i. M82 is the small companion to M81 and their interaction is suggested by radio imagery. It is of type I0 (irregular) and is the closest starburst galaxy to our Milky Way.

item.title: NGC 2403
item.description: NGC 2403 taken with the Canon T5i on the Celestron C11. This is a nearby (3 Mpc) type Scd galaxy. It is nearly bulgeless.
item.media:description: NGC 2403 taken with the Canon T5i on the Celestron C11. This is a nearby (3 Mpc) type Scd galaxy. It is nearly bulgeless.

item.title: 3C 273 - brightest quasar
item.description: 3C 273, a faint (12.9 mag) dot in the circle, is the brightest quasar in the sky and one of the closest. Distance = 750 Mpc (2.4 billion LY). Type blazar. This 120 sec exposure is not long enough or clear enough to bring out the optical jet.
item.media:description: 3C 273, a faint (12.9 mag) dot in the circle, is the brightest quasar in the sky and one of the closest. Distance = 750 Mpc (2.4 billion LY). Type blazar. This 120 sec exposure is not long enough or clear enough to bring out the optical jet.

item.title: M51- Whirlpool Galaxy
item.description:
M51, the Whirlpool Galaxy. This spiral galaxy is unusual in that it is interacting with a dwarf irregular galaxy (NGC 5195) nearby. It is grand design spiral of type Sbc.
DSI II CCD, Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor.
item.media:description:
M51, the Whirlpool Galaxy. This spiral galaxy is unusual in that it is interacting with a dwarf irregular galaxy (NGC 5195) nearby. It is grand design spiral of type Sbc.
DSI II CCD, Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor.

item.title: M101
item.description:
M101, also known as the Pinwheel Galaxy. This grand-design spiral galaxy is of type Sc.
DSI II CCD on the Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor.
item.media:description:
M101, also known as the Pinwheel Galaxy. This grand-design spiral galaxy is of type Sc.
DSI II CCD on the Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor.

item.title: M101
item.description:
M101 in 2013. Comparison with previous 2011 picture reveals some colorful hot pixels (not to be confused with supernovae).
DSI II CCD, Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor. The arms should have a bluer color.
item.media:description:
M101 in 2013. Comparison with previous 2011 picture reveals some colorful hot pixels (not to be confused with supernovae).
DSI II CCD, Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor. The arms should have a bluer color.

item.title: M31
item.description:
M31
DSI II CCD with 12" Meade LX200.
item.media:description:
M31
DSI II CCD with 12" Meade LX200.

item.title: M110
item.description:
M110- a dwarf galaxy that is a satellite of the Andromeda Galaxy.
DSI II CCD, Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor.
item.media:description:
M110- a dwarf galaxy that is a satellite of the Andromeda Galaxy.
DSI II CCD, Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor.

item.title: M82 with supernova
item.description: Messier 82 (nearby starburst) taken while there was a supernova going off in 2014. This image is flipped vertically from the true orientation.
item.media:description: Messier 82 (nearby starburst) taken while there was a supernova going off in 2014. This image is flipped vertically from the true orientation.

item.title: M31 center
item.description: The center of Sb galaxy M31, the closest bright spiral to the Milky Way. Distance=2.4 MLY. Patchy dust is visible around the nucleus.
item.media:description: The center of Sb galaxy M31, the closest bright spiral to the Milky Way. Distance=2.4 MLY. Patchy dust is visible around the nucleus.

item.title: M31
item.description:
M31 (center) with satellite ellipticals M32 (below) and M110 (above, right). A bit out of focus, but good for showing the dust lanes in M31.
Atik 383L CCD on the 80 mm Meade APO refractor.
item.media:description:
M31 (center) with satellite ellipticals M32 (below) and M110 (above, right). A bit out of focus, but good for showing the dust lanes in M31.
Atik 383L CCD on the 80 mm Meade APO refractor.

item.title: M31 (Andromeda Galaxy)
item.description: Close up of the bulge of M31, the Andromeda galaxy. Taken with the Atik CCD through RGB filters using the Celestron C11. The dust absorption is stronger on the top side because that is the closer side to us.
item.media:description: Close up of the bulge of M31, the Andromeda galaxy. Taken with the Atik CCD through RGB filters using the Celestron C11. The dust absorption is stronger on the top side because that is the closer side to us.

item.title: M33
item.description:
M33 in the constellation Triangulum. N is up and E to left.
Atik 383L CCD on the Meade 80 mm APO. 13 exposures were aligned and combined.
item.media:description:
M33 in the constellation Triangulum. N is up and E to left.
Atik 383L CCD on the Meade 80 mm APO. 13 exposures were aligned and combined.

item.title: M33
item.description: M33 in Triangulum. N is up. Atik 383L CCD on the 80 mm APO. Display adjusted to reveal nucleus but not outer arms.
item.media:description: M33 in Triangulum. N is up. Atik 383L CCD on the 80 mm APO. Display adjusted to reveal nucleus but not outer arms.

item.title: M33 in color
item.description: M33 in color. Taken with Atik CCD on the Celestron C11.
item.media:description: M33 in color. Taken with Atik CCD on the Celestron C11.

item.title: M33 (negative)
item.description: An color inverted, black and white view of M33. N is up and E to the left. Atik CCD on the 80 mm APO refracter.
item.media:description: An color inverted, black and white view of M33. N is up and E to the left. Atik CCD on the 80 mm APO refracter.

item.title: Leo Triplet
item.description: The Leo Triplet taken with the Atik CCD on the Meade 12-inch. The triplet includes M65 (top right), M66 (lower right), and NGC 3628 (left). Hot pixels and cosmic rays have not yet been removed.
item.media:description: The Leo Triplet taken with the Atik CCD on the Meade 12-inch. The triplet includes M65 (top right), M66 (lower right), and NGC 3628 (left). Hot pixels and cosmic rays have not yet been removed.

item.title: M31- Andromeda Galaxy
item.description:
M31, also known as the Andromeda Galaxy. This galaxy is the nearest spiral galaxy to our own, and can be seen with the naked eye in the constellation Andromeda. It is of classification Sb. The fuzzy orb below center is M32, and elliptical galaxy orbitting M31. North is up and East to the left.
Atik 383L CCD on the Meade 80 mm APO provides about a 2-degree vertical field of view.
item.media:description:
M31, also known as the Andromeda Galaxy. This galaxy is the nearest spiral galaxy to our own, and can be seen with the naked eye in the constellation Andromeda. It is of classification Sb. The fuzzy orb below center is M32, and elliptical galaxy orbitting M31. North is up and East to the left.
Atik 383L CCD on the Meade 80 mm APO provides about a 2-degree vertical field of view.

item.title: M66
item.description: Messier 66 taken with the Canon T5i on the Celestron C11. This 60 sec exposure is not deep enough to see the full extent of the spiral arms, but the colors are fairly accurate. This is an SAB(s)b galaxy in the Leo triplet
item.media:description: Messier 66 taken with the Canon T5i on the Celestron C11. This 60 sec exposure is not deep enough to see the full extent of the spiral arms, but the colors are fairly accurate. This is an SAB(s)b galaxy in the Leo triplet

item.title: M81 (NGC 3031)
item.description: M81 taken with the Canon T5i on Celestron 11-inch. M81 is considered a grand design spiral with Hubble type Sab (unbarred).
item.media:description: M81 taken with the Canon T5i on Celestron 11-inch. M81 is considered a grand design spiral with Hubble type Sab (unbarred).
